One thing to keep in mind is that "races" is relative.
For example, we call all Africans blacks, but distinguish Polish, German, Anglo, Italian, Irish.
If this was a Jap board, I'd be telling you how we call whites a race, but distinguish Korean, Han, Ughyur, Thai, etc.
If this was an African board, I'd be telling you how we call Asians a race, but distinguish Bantu, Ethiopians, Somalis, Nigerians, Malians, etc.

But overall, you can divide the world into probably 5 subspecies that roughly match those traditional ones.

com:
>>10420670
>usually geographically isolated population of organisms

I'm more willing to accept that Homo erectus had proper subspecies compared to us, because we did something Homo erectus apparently never really did: We race mixed. Constantly. Even in our early days in Africa, Homo sapiens was mixing with other divergent populations of Homo sapiens to create future people down the line, and Eurasians kept migrating back into Africa for tens of thousands of years. Not even the Australian Aboriginals were 100% isolated, as they have some genes from Southern Indians. Now, if all the races of the world stayed apart from each other for tens of thousands of years more, then we'd get proper subspecies like Homo erectus. Pic related, Homo erectus georgicus, all dated to a similar time frame, abound 1.5-1.8 million years ago, in the country Georgia. They had more phenotypical variance in that population than most people do world wide.

Why is the existence of "race-mixing" be in anyway relevant? The definition already includes successful interbreeding, so I see no point in making this vague feature a categorical term.
Homo erectus did interbreed with us. Africans still have homo erectus DNA, so if there is at least one "homo erectus" alive today, would that by your definition make them part of your definition of species anyways?

Several subspecies of other animals "race-mixed" due to sharing some territory with other subspecies. Even more today, since global warming is making polar bears migrate south that they interbreed with grizzly bears, and they make fertile offspring. So are those bear species no longer separate?

It seems like your definition is vague, and just human-centric. It does not seem to apply to all species, i.e. special pleading.

>>10421142
>Africans still have homo erectus DNA

We don't even have verifiable Homo erectus DNA from the many fossils that we have today. Judging from how Homo erectus vanishes from Africa's fossil record a couple hundred thousand years before Homo sapiens evolved, whatever the three archaic hominins that are in multiple African (and Eurasian, thanks to the most recent one found in West Africans) populations today would likely not be Homo erectus. Now, the superarchaic DNA found in Neanderthals and Denisovans would be a better candidate, as it shows up right before both of those species split into two.

com:
>>10421060
Fun fact, the Khoisan people and another, pre-Bantu South-African tribe, the Hadza are the most genetically distant people groups on Earth. It has been said that the three primary genetic divisions of humanity are the Hadza, the Khoisan, then everyone else.

Despite the apparent diversity of races, the human gene pool is extremely shallow. Fucking chimps have bigger genetic diversity between populations than humans, despite having tiny populations confined to a small region in Africa. This is an evidence of a recent genetic bottleneck, i.e. most people are the descendants of a handful of people that lived relatively recently.

https://www.ox.ac.uk/news/2012-03-02-chimps-show-much-greater-genetic-diversity-humans

name: Anonymous
com:
>>10422149
Only naledi, floresiensis-like dwarf and any other hominins related to them would be considered microcephalic by own standards. And in the case of floresiensis it's only due to a smaller overall body size to correspond with their smaller brains, so it's not like they'd actually look like people with small heads for their size. Only naledi has an especially small microcephaly tier brain for its body size because it's pretty much the same height as a Modern human pygmy but with a much smaller endocranial volume. Even superarchaic late erectus and archaic hominins (not including big brained Neanderthals, mind you) all had brain size overlapping with modern humans, ranging between 1000-1400 CC. Which is pretty much the same as certain populations of Modern Humans that have average of 1100-1200 CC. Late surviving Archaics and Superarchaics had modern tier cranial capacities for all intents and purposes and you wouldn't mistake them for guy with microcephaly.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>10425393
Sima de los Huesos heidelbergensis ranges from 1125 CC (skull 5) to 1390 CC (skull 4). Antecessor from Spain falls in between 1000 CC and 1150 CC. Both of these sets of remains predate the earliest Homo sapiens at rougly 300,000 years and trends in hominin encephalization was only in increasing in size until about 10,000 years ago when it started decreasing, so it's very likely antecessor-like and heidelbergensis-like forms that coexisted with our species had even larger brains that fell exactly in our range. Ngangong erectus soloensis ranges from 1013-1251 CC and it coexisted temporally with us.
https://www.nature.com/articles/362534a0

name: Anonymous
com:
>>10425393
Xuchang had a mosaic of Neanderthal and Modern Human like features. Denisovans disproportionately share more characteristics in skeletal anatomy and morphology with their Neanderthal sister species rather than with us >>10425316, so this makes me think Xuchang represents something else entirely, perhaps some kind of hybrid.
>The skulls lack faces and jaws. But they include enough undistorted pieces for the team to note a close resemblance to Neandertals. One cranium has a huge brain volume of 1800 cubic centimeters—on the upper end for both Neandertals and moderns—plus a Neandertal-like hollow in a bone on the back of its skull. Both crania have prominent brow ridges and inner ear bones that resemble those of Neandertals but are distinct from our own species, Homo sapiens.
>However, the crania also differ from the western Neandertals of Europe and the Middle East. They have thinner brow ridges and less robust skull bones, similar to early modern humans and some other Asian fossils. “They are not Neandertals in the full sense,” says co-author Erik Trinkaus, a paleoanthropologist at Washington University in St. Louis in Missouri.
Pic related is Hualongdong and older than Xuchang. It suspiciously resembles the likes of Jebel Irhoud, a very early H. sapiens.

That hominin in that picture is Homo erectus, an outdated depiction of one based on Meganthropus. This is what Homo heidelbergensis in Africa (or Homo rhodesiensis) looked like.

https://advances.sciencemag.org/content/6/7/eaax5097

This is from Wikipedia.

>According to a study published in 2020, there are indications that 2% to 19% (or about ≃6.6 and ≃7.0%) of the DNA of four West African populations may have come from an unknown archaic hominin which split from the ancestor of humans and Neanderthals between 360 kya to 1.02 mya. However, the study also finds that at least part of this proposed archaic admixture is also present in Eurasians/non-Africans, and that the admixture event or events range from 0 to 124 ka B.P, which includes the period before the Out-of-Africa migration and prior to the African/Eurasian split (thus affecting in part the common ancestors of both Africans and Eurasians/non-Africans). Another recent study, which discovered substantial amounts of previously undescribed human genetic variation, also found ancestral genetic variation in Africans that predates modern humans and was lost in most non-Africans.


https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interbreeding_between_archaic_and_modern_humans

That picture was created in bad faith, picking an African American with extreme prognathism as a typical African.

Is floresiensis descended from Javan erectus or an earlier hominin like dmanisi-esque forms of erectus or even habilis/rudolfensis?

name: Anonymous
com:
>>10426878
It has automorphisms more similar to australopiths in its feet and hand bones but its teeth are more like that of erectus. Really depends which way you're looking at it from, if you favor using feet and hands as a diagnostic for phylogeny then floresiensis is descended from habilis/rudolfensis or something like them. If you favor using teeth as a diagnostic for determining the relationship between taxons, then erectus would be your best bet as the ancestor. Whether or not it's a tall long limbed form of erectus like Turkana boy or short limbed form of erectus like Dmanisi was the ancestor of floresiensis is up for debate. Though the fact that the populations ancestral to late Pleistocene floresiensis were even smaller than their descendants lends more credence to the latter hypothesis being true.
Sources: https://repository.si.edu/bitstream/handle/10088/6090/Tocheri_2007the_primitive_wrist_of.pdf
https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2009Natur.459...81J
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4651360/

Africa is outdated, there are three species that modern humans interbred with in the continent (West Africans and Eurasians sharing one in common, since it happened before the most recent waves of Homo sapiens left the continent, and Pygmies, Khoisan, and other hunter gatherer groups have two), and Eurasians might have a third, unknown human species in their genes that could account for the ambiguous remnants.

https://www.sciencealert.com/artificial-intelligence-identifies-unknown-ghost-ancestor-in-the-human-genome

Geneticists don't know whether it was a species closely related to both Neanderthals and Denisovans, a species or extremely derived subspecies that split very early on from Denisovans, or an outright hybrid species descended from both, but regardless, its in there.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>10428599
It's crazy to think that an actually different, older subspecies of Homo sapiens was living in Africa up until the Neolithic, but it's also interesting to note that these guys might actually be the "Ghost Homo Sapiens" population found in African genes.

>https://www.eurekalert.org/pub_releases/2020-01/slu-nsf012220.php

>Our analysis indicates the existence of at least four major deep human lineages that contributed to people living today, and which diverged from each other between about 250,000 and 200,000 years ago," said David Reich, Ph.D., of Harvard Medical School, senior author of the study.

>These lineages are ancestral to present-day central African hunter-gatherers, southern African hunter-gatherers, and all other modern humans, with a fourth lineage being a previously unknown 'ghost population' that contributed a small amount of ancestry to both western and eastern Africans. "This quadruple radiation--including the position of a deeply-splitting 'ghost' modern human lineage--had not been identified before from DNA," Reich said.

Interesting tidbit: Most black Africans share a common ancestor about 60,000-80,000 years old, which is right around the time proto-Eurasians started to leave Africa.

>Analysis also revealed another set of four human lineages branching between 80,000 and 60,000 years ago, including the lineages contributing most the ancestry in present-day eastern and western Africans and all non-Africans.

So in short, about 200,000-250,000 years ago, there were 3 populations in Africa that would eventually make up humans today, and a another that only left a small amount of genes: The ancestors of the Khoisan, a older, divergent lineage unknown to the fossil record, the ancestors of Pygmy people, and the ancestors of West Africans (and by default, Bantus many tens of thousands of years later), Nilotes and Horners(East Africans), and Eurasians.

The Campanian Ignimbrite Eruption wiped out both the last Neanderthals and pre Aurignacians Modern Human populations (as represented by the likes of Oase and Bacho Kiro) in Europe. It's just that since Modern Humans had a wider geographic range they didn't have all their eggs in one basket compared to Neanderthals whom were more vulnerable since they had lower numbers and more of their geographic range was in the fallout of the eruption relative to Modern Humans. So when both Neanderthals and pre Aurignacian EEMHs were wiped out there were only Modern Humans from less affected regions like the Middle East while could move into a largely depopulated Europe and these are of course Aurignacians.

com:
>>10430077
I have a few problems with this, even though it's mostly alright. The genes that make up very dark skin (you know, from dark chocolate to almost jet black) are actually older than Homo sapiens, and date back to around 500,000 years, alongside other shades of brown. The other thing is lumping West Africans, Bantus, and Nilo-Saharans under "Bantuid", when Bantus are actually much younger than basically every single African racial/ethnic group on that list, outside of maybe Horners. The third and final thing is that Melanesians didn't re-evolve very dark skin for their humid tropical environment, they've had that for a very long time. A good example of people who started out lighter but became darker over time would be the Sinhalese of Sri Lanka.

>They were like little men, about 4 feet high, walking upright, but clad in russet hair. The native hunter with me gazed in mingled fear and amazement. They were, he said, agogwe, the little furry men whom one does not see once in a lifetime.

>In 1927 I was with my wife coasting Portuguese East Africa in a Japanese cargo boat. We were sufficiently near to land to see objects clearly with a glass of twelve magnifications. There was a sloping beach with light bush above upon which several dozen baboons where hunting for and picking up shell fish of crabs, to judge by their movements. Two pure white baboons were amongst them. These are very rare but I had heard of them previously. As we watched, two little brown men walked together out of the bush and down amongst the baboons. They were certainly not any known monkey and yet they must have been akin or they would have disturbed the baboons. They were too far away to be seen in great detail, but these small human-like animals were probably between four and five feet tall, quite upright and graceful in figure. At the time I was thrilled as they were quite evidently no beast of which I had heard or read. Later a friend and big game hunter told me he was in Portuguese East Africa with his wife and three other hunters, and saw mother, father and child, of apparently similar animal species, walk across the further side of a bush clearing. The natives loudly forbade him to shoot.

>>10429832
But your own science says that we evolved to cognize whatever passes on genes successfully.

As long as we have a majority of true beliefs and mostly reliable epistemic practices, then having a handful of faulty beliefs and a few faulty epistemic practices won't necessarily impact our reproductive fitness. A belief in a all-seeing God might even benefit reproductive practices by enforcing rules needed for social harmony even when no one is around to observe the wrong-doer.

Religious belief is a problem on the fringes (Jones Town). But really any belief can lead to harmful actions (literal belief in dialectical materialism).

Plus, it's not always easy to categorize beliefs into harmful/non-harmful merely by whether what they refer to exists or not. Beliefs in fiction are often epistemically useful, like the use of a center of gravity or the existence of the 'self' in the mind who we can deem responsible and send the tax bill to each year.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>10429992
This argument is flawed.

We only know of one universe, the one we're in, so that's only one data point. Two data points doesn't really mean much either outside of establishing a weak correlation. Three data points are the minimum before a pattern can begin to be drawn, and even then you're grasping at straws most of the time until you have yet more data. We cannot, therefore, draw meaningful information from the fact that the universe is orderly.

It is just as plausible an explanation that disorderly universes simply do not develop any forms of life capable of observing them, or that disorderly universes cease to exist very quickly, or even that disorderly universes are simply not possible due to some natural property of whatever exists outside of universes.

>>10429592
>Sums up the Catholic mentality perfectly: it's not about God, it's about tradition. They'd still be worshipping Jupiter if Constantine hadn't forced them to adopt at least the trappings of Christianity.

Long before the time of Constantine, Ireneaus (130-202AD) recognized the authority of the Catholic Church.

Thus, Irenaeus wrote in Against Heresies:
>Since, however, it would be very tedious, in such a volume as this, to reckon up the successions of all the Churches, we do put to confusion all those who, in whatever manner, whether by an evil self-pleasing, by vainglory, or by blindness and perverse opinion, assemble in unauthorized meetings; [we do this, I say,] by indicating that tradition derived from the apostles, of the very great, the very ancient, and universally known Church founded and organized at Rome by the two most glorious apostles, Peter and Paul; as also [by pointing out] the faith preached to men, which comes down to our time by means of the successions of the bishops.

>For it is a matter of necessity that every Church should agree with this Church [i.e. the Church at Rome], on account of its preeminent authority.

Note that what he is claiming here is that the Church at Rome, which traces its origin to Peter, is *infallible*, for it would be false that "it is a matter of necessity" that every Church should agree with the Church at Rome, if the Church at Rome could fall into heresy or apostasy.

The idea that every other Church should agree with the Church at Rome depends upon there being some special divine gift of unique authority given to that Church, and thus to the Apostolic founder of the Church at Rome: (i) the whole and complete deposit of faith was entrusted to the Apostles and (ii) there is a divine gift, a charism of truth, by which that deposit is faithfully preserved in the succession of bishops from the Apostles.

The inference of infallibility thus follows necessarily upon Ireneaus's argument.

- Liberated millions from slavery

>>10426066
Mao dealt a heavy blow to Confucianist and traditional values. In order to recalibrate the relationship between man and state, the CCP has to resort to legal measures. Besides social harmony, the social credit system also limits the scope of acceptable political discourse, which in turns strengthens the CCP’s grip on power. Since stability and economic growth can only be achieved through political continuity in China, it’s not surprising that they would be willing to go as far as to intervene into the intimate aspects of private individuals. It’s actually quite interesting that Xi and many other Chinese intellectuals are now placing an emphasis on traditional values, I think it will help strengthen their mandate and ability to govern the country by making the population more subservient or obedient. China has no concept of individual rights, something which is so cherished in the West. So it is difficult for the West to understand why so many Chinese are willing to sacrifice some of their freedoms for the greater “good”. But political differences I think shouldn’t be a point of contention between China and the West. Instead of worrying about how they treat their own citizens, our leaders should focus on ensuring access to Chinese markets instead of criticizing them with the goal of scoring some cheap political points.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>10426066
The primacy of the individual in the West enables the average citizen to be happy as he is left to his own. But it also entails a certain level of disorder that is intolerable in China. By emphasizing the collective instead of the individual, the Chinaman is on average, more disciplined and obedient than his Western counterpart. By putting the state before the individual, the government is more likely to achieve its goals. Take the pandemic for example, mask ordinances in Asia are followed by mostly everyone which in turn has helped stunt the spread of the virus. Something like masks wouldn’t be a political issue in Confucianist countries like China, South Korea and Singapore. It is an issue in the West though because people don’t like being told what to do, and it’s entirely understandable, they don’t like masks and they have doubts of the efficacy. But as a result of this, there has been more deaths. The bottom line is this, the West will never understand China and China will never understand the West. They are two completely distinct civilizations with conflicting norms and values. They can coexist together in an international order, because in the end of the day, it is only money that really matters. Both greatly benefit from access to each others’ markets and it will continue to be that way in the foreseeable future.

The ethical issue is by a government deciding what is and isn't moral and what results in reduced privileges.
With a tool like this a government (any government, particularly an authoritarian one like China's) can silence dissent and criticism very easily, which means it's much more difficult for the citizens to influence the government and much easier for the government to influence it's citizens.
While it makes sense that if a bank knows a person spits on the homeless and throws eggs at the elderly they're probably a bad risk and wouldn't give a loan in good terms, it is absolutely dystopian to ruin a person's career because they criticized the governm- oh, I'm sorry, "spread lies" about the communist party.
Governments can't be trusted to act in the interest of it's people, and the only way to force politicians to serve the interests of the people is by making their political career dependent on the people's satisfaction, that's why democracies are a good place to live in.
The president or prime minister isn't doing what he's doing because he "cares", he does what he's doing because he knows that the voters need to be satisfied if he wants to keep his chair.

Strategically what China's doing is genius, they don't squeeze so hard that things slip between their fingers like in the USSR or in many other authoritarian regimes, their brand of oppression isn't brutal (relatively), they don't suicide opposition members and instead "reeducate" them and present a path to salvation for all the wrong thinkers while also opening up the economy and ensuring people have food and luxuries.
Like with foreign sites, instead of outright blocking Google they just kill every 4th packet or so.
So instead of blocking it and making a person just seek out a proxy, they make Google annoyingly slow and the average man just goes "fuck it, I'll just use the Chinese search engine, I'm just looking for cute cats anyhow".

name: Anonymous
com:
Society runs on social credit already, except that it isn't literally currency, and the system isn't in place mainly to shoehorn government tyranny and mind control. It's a system that exists naturally between people. People who do good things enjoy a better reputation and get better opportunities etc. It would be nice if this arrangement were more consistent or fair than it is, but more rules or more authority won't necessarily improve it.

The problem is having some authority lay out its own rules for what behavior is good and then quantifying it and turning it into a game. The end result is that there are no good or bad citizens, just winners and losers in a perverse social market designed very specifically for the state to abuse for its own institutional ends. For instance, it is bribing and threatening people to turn against their neighbors who might be critical of a government doing what I just now described.

name: Anonymous

>>10431018
Not the anon you're responding to, but I would point out two things.

1) It really wasn't a war fought under the same conditions as WW1. Most of WW1's Eastern Front was being fought in what's now Poland; the climate conditions were quite different from hundreds of miles into Russia where the winter fighting was in WW2.
2) The single biggest impact weather had was on supply, messing up roads and railroads and thus the ability to move cargo and reinforcements that those armies operated on. Germany's entire geostrategic position in WW1 was different than in WW2, and it was neither as reliant upon, nor geared to deliver, rapid knockout blows. The weather upset that ability, which effectively means it hampered the Germans in WW2 more than WW1, even if it's the exact same weather conditions.

Because there was no way they could win that fight, and it would only take them through a bunch of relatively over developed countries to which they wouldn't be able to expand German Industry.

The plan was to acquire the resources that Germany needed so that it would no longer be dependent on the British empire/US (IE: crucially oil, but also agriculture and metals) whilst also expanding Germany's influence into underdeveloped foreign markets, which Germany could then develop to take advantage of the cheap labour (during war they imported/enslaved this labour).
At that point Germany and it's allies could build it's self into a force that could actually challenge US financial and industrial domination.

They were in a somewhat similar situation to China is today, strategic resource poor but industry rich, they were arguably at a later stage though with industry even more desperate to expand outside of the national borders.
They were also relatively weaker.

>>10430550
>Sutton's works have received a number of criticisms from other academics, particularly in regards to his Wall Street trilogy (Wall Street and the Bolshevik Revolution, Wall Street and FDR, and Wall Street and the Rise of Hitler)".[13][14] Some historians argue that these books more closely resemble conspiracy theory than genuine historical studies. For instance, in a contemporary review of Sutton's Wall Street and the Bolshevik Revolution, researcher Virgil D. Medlin of Oklahoma City University reported finding numerous factual errors in the book and claimed that Sutton repeated "unsubstantiated allegations [and came to] unwarranted conclusions." Medlin also stated Sutton made use of dubious sources, such as rumor and uncorroborated inquiries, as "documentary proof of [his] allegations."[13] Similarly, Howard Dickman of the Manhattan Institute for Policy Research referred to Sutton's Wall Street and FDR as a "weak specimen of conspiracy history" that was "poorly written and edited, digressive, repetitious, disorganized, and unconvincing."[14]

>Sutton's Western Technology and Soviet Economic Development, 1945 to 1965 has also received criticism, specifically in regards to its thesis. Dr. Samuel Lieberstein of Temple University had initially praised the first two volumes of the study but later came to criticize it in his review of the third volume, stating that Sutton failed to note instances of Soviet technological innovation and ignored positive aspects of the USSR's planned economy that seemed to conflict with his thesis.[15] British historian Richard C. Thurlow also criticized Sutton's thesis stating that "all nations were dependent on international trade for economic development and their industrial infrastructure, including the United States" adding that Sutton "totally [disregarded] alternative explanations of Soviet industrialization".[16]

The Ottomans were too poor to do much of anything, but the Russians and Austrians actually did try to modernize their armies before ww1. The Austrian cavalry reforms were revolutionary, even without the British's practical experience of fighting against the Boers they still independently came to the conclusion that all cavalry needed to be homogenous and focus more on marksmanship than charges. In 1914 Austria had the second most modern cavalry force in the world, it's just a shame that 1. This would not be a war of cavalry and 2. For every Austrian horseman there were 3 Russian horsemen. Austrian artillery training was also to a great standard and their guns had very high quality sights.
The Russians, with their Russo-Japanese war experience had double the number of machine guns the Germans had at the start of the war, they had hands down the most machine guns of any nation.

name: Anonymous
com:
Why was the US that emerged from the Civil War not considered a 2nd republic? Clearly it had been radically changed and the tensions of early america boiled over into something very different. Was it just for the sake of continuity and pacification?

Though I suppose the ungraceful abandonment of a half-assed reconstruction and the revival of old southern politics effectively meant that the original form of the nation was more or less restored? It would be a very long time until the West was a serious counterweight to the northern/southern political divide, and today it seems there has been an effective political merger of the north and the south, with both Democrats and Republicans having their financial and political foundations in the south and midwest. The fact that the Clintons are from the south and the Bushes are from New England seems to be obscured by their playing to the opposite regions cultural sensibilities.

Of course the Confederacy as a military rebellion was defeated, but would it be fair to say that the Southern political institutions it represented have a real continuity with the US government today, and were not destroyed but only disarmed and forcibly reincorporated? Or was the Civil War actually a meaningful enough break in US political continuity that the post-war republic can be seen, maybe a bit polemically but with some real basis, as a 2nd American Republic?

name: Anonymous
com:
>>10432141
Why would it be a 2nd republic? 99% of the constitution stayed the same, a part of the US that seceded was just taken back.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>10432344
14th amendment though. The words of the constitution stayed the same, but their range and effect increased massively post civil war.

Still not sure if that’s enough to make it a 2nd republic like OP asks about though.

name: Anonymous
com: Continuity of government was preserved. The French Republics were replaced by completely different systems

name: Anonymous
com:
>>10432344
Reconstruction Amendments. Secession was formally made illegal. The diverging opinions on the nature of the federal system were squashed; the Union was enshrined as perpetual. Its an interesting question and it undeniably is the pivotal moment that sets the stage for the unrelenting expansion of federal authority since then.

>>10432141
The Southern political institutions did continue to exist but in a much weaker state, especially financially as they had lost their source of wealth (slaves) and the Northern industrial and banking tycoons really blew up in the post-war Gilded era.

The North did not have the strength to utterly destroy the South, nor did it WANT too-Northern racism meant that they wanted Southern whites in charge, but loyal to DC. They didn't want them in charge and doing their own thing, hence why the Reconstruction Amendments elevated black status, to be used as a fifth column against the weakened Southern society. These cracks would grow and grow, despite revanchist efforts of Southern intelligentsia and politicians to curtail it, until its final death after the Civil Rights movement. At which point, the Southern political institutions were finally destroyed.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>10428263
This curious hat goes by various names, bocca, boqta, boghtagh. This style of hat was used by Mongolian and other steppe noble women, especially the Khatun, to show off their wealth and power. The richer the lady was, the more ornate the hat was expected to be, because who would want to be the richest lady with the worst hat? Since these objects were worn by noble women, and they were expensive and prized, they would also be used as gifts just as a sable coat would be. Of course, the rich people could afford to buy rare jewels and other expensive objects because the Mongolian conquests of such a vast region made transportation of these objects along the silk road possible.

William of Rubruck writes about it while on his journey in the Mongol world. He states that the hat is made of tree bark, or if they can use a lighter material they will. Rubruck also gives measurements of the hat, which is about half a foot in width, and at least 1.5ft in height.1 Rubruck goes into a good amount of detail regarding how the hat is composed. The hat is hollow, because otherwise it would be even more cumbersome to wear, there are peacock and other fowl’s feathers on top of the square part of the hat (which add yet another 1.5ft or more in height), the shaft of the hat is decorated with stones and other precious materials and had a fur hood that the shaft was attached to.2 While donning the hat, unless they were bald, the ladies would have to tie their hair into a knot so the bocca hat could be tied around the throat with the chin strap.3

name: Anonymous
com:
>>10428263
>>10428314

Rubruck wasn’t the only one to comment on the bocca hats. Marco Polo was so impressed with the hats that he brought one back to Venice. According to the Travels of Chang Chun, “They are always in fear that somebody might inadvertently run against this cap. Therefore, when entering a tent, they are accustomed to go backward, inclining their heads.”4 Another observer is Carpini, and he states that, “The cap as well as this object is covered with buckram, velvet, or brocade, and without this headgear they never go into the presence of men and by it they are distinguished from other women."5 By the time of Timur, the hat was still in style and even more ornate. Clavijo visited the Timur’s court and noted that Timur’s wife was wearing a bocca and said, “In the back part this crest was very lofty and it was ornamented with many great round pearls all of good orient, also with precious stones such as balas rubies and turquoises, the same very finely set.”6

1. Willem Van Ruysbroeck, Peter Jackson, and David Morgan, The Mission of Friar William of Rubruck: His Journey to the Court of the Great Khan Möngke, 1253-1255 (London: Hakluyt Society, 1990). p. 88
2. Ruysbroeck, p. 89
3. Ruysbroeck, p. 89
4. "Ch'ang Ch'un's Travels," 2003, , accessed June 07, 2018, https://depts.washington.edu/silkroad/texts/changchun.html.
5. Laurence Bergreen, Marco Polo: From Venice to Xanadu (London: Quercus, 2009). p. 62-63
6. Ruy González De Clavijo and G. Le Strange, Embassy to Tamerlane, 1403-1406 (Kilkerran: Hardinge Simpole, 2009). p. 136

name: Anonymous
com:
>>10420510
>>10420562
The amount of knowledge lost due to the Spanish mass book burnings is a wierd thing to try to describe.

On one hand, it's hard to overstate things: Writing in Mesoamerica goes back 2500 years before the Spanish arrived. Most major Mesoamerican civilizations had some sort of written script, and we know that some cities had large libraries: Tenochtitan and Texcoco, the two most powerful Aztec cities, both had large collections of books of tax and adminstrative records, political genealogies and animistic records/historical texts, and religious documents, maybe other kinds beyond these. We have less then 20 surviving Prehispanic texts: Everything from those libraries was burned, Diego De Landa burned likely hundreds, maybe thousands of Maya books, and likewise there were probably hundreds or thousands of Mixtec, Zapotec, etc and other texts lost too.From the 8 Mixtec books that survive, we have a through political history of the areas they cover going back 800 years. It's sort of insane to think about the amount of records we would have if we had 50, 100, or 500 surviving prehsiapnic books instead of the dozen and half we do.

In some respects, we basically lost an entire third pillar of human civilization and history alongside the West and East. I've seen it said that the burnings are why Mesoamerica is an archaeological rather then a historical topic. The entire conception of world history and how it's taught could be radically different if we had more surviving texts. If Mesoamerican culture itself survived and continued, then it'd probably get talked about as much as Greece/Rome or China/Japan is, and would get a ton of usage in general pop culture (imagine Aztec culture being used just as much in games and film as Japanese, Mexico still with active, kept up pyramids and palaces tourists could go inside, etc) and in education.

1/?
filename: The Spanish burning Aztec books, Codex Tlaxcala

name: Anonymous
com:
>>10427175
>>10420510
>>10420562
cont:

On the other hand, While only 4 Maya books survive, there's hundreds, if not thousands of inscriptions each detailing their political histories (albiet in a dry "On X day Y happened" format mostly) which survive in ruins, and. as I said, the 8 surviving Mixtec books similarly recording political history in the valley they cover going back 800 years, and by virtue of the Aztec being the preeminent power in the region and Spain largely continuing to place political importance on them, there's HUNDREDS of documents on Aztec history and society surviving from the early colonial period from both Spanish and Aztec authors re-recording information

Sahagun's history for instance is like 2000+ pages of detailed info on daily life, government organization, culture, and general society; from judicial systems to merchantry to medicine to figures of speech, while Duran's history is a similar work but detailing their history, down to specific statements made by specific political officials, see pic. (tho these are best seen as romantized histrory/legend, and there's some distortion from being made under spanish oversight) There's been entire books written about specific political officials, like "Allure of Nezahualcoyotl" and "Tlaclelel remembered", compilations of poetry, etc. There's some documents like this (though not as many or as in depth)( on the Maya, to a lesser extent the Zapotec, Mixtec, etc as well.

It's really only for other civilizations where there's almost nothing, with only single inscriptions or only 1-2 colonial period documents, like the Purepecha (the third largest state in the Americas after the Inca and Aztec) have the Relación de Michoacán, and then a few Relacion de Geograficas for some specific towns and that's mostly it, let alone stuff like the Zoque, Mixe, Chinantec, etc but even then archaeology can tell a lot

See also: https://arch.b4k.co/v/thread/541343303/#541345210

It wasn't inevitable

The Conquest playing out how it did was extremely reliant on early flukes then snowballing out of control. Spain wasn't particularly invested in mass scale colonization as we think of it intially. It was the success of Cortes's expedition being so lucrative, with tons of wealth and riches found, many former Aztec subject states now sending taxes/tribute to Spain, the establishment of New Spain/Mexico city giving them a base of operations, and having establishjed infanstructure and manpower from the former Aztec Empire and their subject armies made further campaigns be both viable and worth the effort to pursue it.

Had Cortes failed (and he so, so so nearly did so many times), then it's possible Spain never gets that push into fully commiting to mass, rapid campaigns; never seeing it as worth the effort: Even when relying on allied armies and the native population being decimated historically, it still took them decades, in some places centuries to conquer it. Doing so without those allies would be a ton of work, when they could invade Africa or the Near East for less effort for more garunteed returns. Diseases were also only as bad as they were historically because. Spain was able to make large headway early on, with a sustained occupation and further campaigns causing REPEATED outbreaks, exacerbated by the political instability, drop in sanitation standards, etc. Without that they won't be as bad and the longer Spain waits, the more time for disease resistance to build.

Obvously it's not like the Americas escapes colonization entirely, but you'd probably see lesser population losses, and more reliance indirect colonialism more in line with what happened in India and Southeast Asia, with existing states and socities kept intact, but suffering East India Company esque shenanigans.

You're very ignorant (Diego De Landa himself described the Maya script /burning maya books), read my posts in arch.b4k.co/v/thread/541343303/#541345210 and below

Almost ever major Mesoamerican civilization had a script, and used either inscriptions in stone or books made from either bark paper (made the same way as eurasian paper) or deer skins. These books are pretty much just like Western books in style, they're just made from single long sheets folded over itself like an accordian rather then multiple sheets bound together, see pic

The complexity of these scripts do vary: The Aztec and Mixtec scripts are almost entirely pictographic, with only limited phonetic elements and rebuses, but you can glean a lot of granular information even from these. Moving up in complexity (or really, moving towards more language based), you have Teotihuacano, which is debated to be either mostly pictographic or logogrammic, and the Zapotec and Epi-Olmec scripts, which were logogram based; tho with the former still having some pictographic and phonetic elements, and lacks articles and propositions and conjugiation; with the latter uses subglyphs representing sounds to form word glyphs like the Maya script which suggests a similar heavy phonetic competent

The Maya script, meanwhile, is unarguably a true, complete written language, one of only 3 known instances of independent full written languages globally. It's a complete phonetic script, with characters representing each spoken syllable of the spoken language, which combine to form word glyphs. Theres also a set of logograms that can be freeily mixed into and with those syllabic characters and word glyph. See: www.youtube.com/watch?v=lgsQndSyfHg They even did shit like making sentences out of ornate drawings of gods associated with specific numbers or dates contorted into the shape of characters to get both the content of of the inscription as well as the date conveyed

As noted in >>10427212 they were comparable to Iron Age, Classical, and Medieval societies in Europe in a number of ways.

Even if you don't consider the historical/cultural losses to be important (which would be absurd. Imagine if Japan got colonized and none of their history, mythology, art etc that gets used in media existed), there are outright potential lost/delayed scientific knowledge.

EX: Maya may have built the world's first true suspension bridge at Yaxchilan. The Aztec had the first public education systems, and as noted in >>10427212 had cutting edge sanitation, medicine, and botany

Bathing was expected extremely regularly, even for commoners, with baths being common even in the most rural, tiniest villages. The amount of bathing the Mesoamericans did (not just the Aztec) was so much higher then what the Spanish were used to, some Spainards literally thought that the reason they kept dying of smallpox was because they bathed too much. Washing one's hands, face, and teeth multiple times a day was expected, as was keeping cleanly shaven.

The Aztec also had the earliest complete understanding of the circulatory system, the first use of intramedullary nails as a surgical treatment for bone fractures, and the first formal taxonomic systems for plant life, centuries before Carl Linnaeus. The Aztec actually had a huge corpus of botanical and medical science in general, with multiple Europeans traveling to mexico to document it, including the Royal Spanish Court Physician and Naturalist Francisco Hernández de Toledo, who (alongside Cortes and others) claimed the Aztec had superior medical science. To this day people are studying Mesoamerican herbal remedies and are finding new herbal treatments. The first birth control pill was synthesized from a Mesoamerican aborifcant, for example.

Happy to post sources for this. I'd do a 10+ post long dump on it but I never slept last night and am tired

I don't care about making either side out to be innocent or evil, but you're very mistaken.

The Mesoamericans didn't raise people for consumption, or practice any sort of dietary scale cannibalism at all: The researcher who proposed that they committed cannibalism for protein intake, Harner, made a ton of errors, such as overlooking tons of protein sources in the Mesoamerican diet, like Nixtamalized maize, chia, amaranth, insects,etc. Most severely, he overlooked that using humans for protein intake for other humans isn't feasible to begin with: It takes more protein to raise a person then you get via consuming them.Even Harner himself admitted that actual Mesoamerican cannibalism was limited to specific ritualistic circumstances: There's no archaeological support for mass cannablism, nor is there much textual evidence for it. It only shows up in specific accounts which go out of their way to demonize the native populations, while more detailed record like Sahagun's Florentine Codex directly contradict the idea.

Them sacrificing hundreds of thousands of innocents a year is straight up, 100% confirmed to be explicitly false:

The vast majority of sacrificial burials only have bodies in the double digits, were deposited to across long time periods to boot. We only found ANY evidence of mass scale sacrifices recently, with the redsicovery of Tenochtitlan's skull rack, but those findings found that the rack, at it's maximum extent, housed merely 11,700 skulls. The underlying towers it had also only had roughly 500 skulls deposited to it over a 16 year time span. The findings also found that 75% of the skulls found were men, most of whom were warriors, see pic.

Even high end extrapolations from those findings would give you annual sacrifice rates of maybe 2-3 thousand people a year, again, most of whom would be warriors, not innocent people. I can go into the math, if you'd like.

The knots aren't mayan at all, they're an Andean invention called a quipu. Quipus made sense for their use case and where they came from.

In the Andes, wood is not a super common resource, and it's additionally hard to move it around. This is why they were so good at stone construction. However, a super common and easily movable resource was textiles, specifically llama textiles. So, over many years, the quipu was developed to do accounting and evolved into a general information storing system, the capabilities of which are kinda unclear because we've lost the ability to decipher anything other than the numerical information. But according to the Spanish themselves, quipu readers in the Inca empire did accounting much more accurately than what the Spanish tried...

Chapter IX.
Of Free Will.

I. God hath endued the will of man with that natural liberty, that is neither forced, nor by any absolute necessity of nature determined to good or evil.(a)

(a) Matt. 17:12; James 1:14; Deut. 30:19.

II. Man, in his state of innocency, had freedom and power to will and to do that which was good, and well pleasing to God;(b) but yet, mutably, so that he might fall from it.(c)

(b) Eccles. 7:29; Gen. 1:26.
(c) Gen. 2:16, 17; Gen. 3:6.

III. Man, by his fall into a state of sin, hath wholly lost all ability of will to any spiritual good accompanying salvation:(d) so as, a natural man, being altogether averse from that good,(e) and dead in sin,(f) is not able, by his own strength, to convert himself, or to prepare himself thereunto.(g)

(d) Rom. 5:6; Rom 8:7; John 15:5.
(e) Rom. 3:10, 12.
(f) Eph. 2:1, 5; Col. 2:13.
(g) John 6:44, 65; Eph. 2:2, 3, 4, 5; I Cor. 2:14; Titus 3:3, 4, 5.

IV. When God converts a sinner, and translates him into the state of grace, He freeth him from his natural bondage under sin;(h) and, by His grace alone, enables him freely to will and to do that which is spiritually good;(i) yet so, as that by reason of his remaining corruption, he doth not perfectly, nor only, will that which is good, but doth also will that which is evil.(k)

(i) Phil. 2:13; Rom. 6:18, 22.
(k) Gal. 5:17; Rom. 7:15, 18, 19, 21, 23.

V. The will of man is made perfectly and immutably free to do good alone, in the state of glory only.(l)

(l) Eph. 4:13; Heb. 12:23; I John 3:2; Jude ver. 24.

False.

Einkorn wheat, the first ever grain-wheat cultivar (predating corn and rice b t w ) is native only to the Konya plains of Turkey. It was cultivated there from wild strains for the first time, and spread rapidly with neolithic expansion (across europe, asia, africa). The cities arose from those hills-plains that continue the Konya-plateau. The cities of Mesopotamia came from this food-source. There were cities first in the middle of the 'fertile crescent', the portion in Turkey. name: Anonymous
com:
>>10428301
What you're saying is simply not true. Everywhere associated with IE expansion is associated with fair skin. I don't give a shit either way, but you are lying and I don't know why. Certain genes associated with light skin took over Europe in a selective sweep but by all indications the lack of that gene in the Yamnaya did not make them dusky. It's not only one possible gene that controls for skin pigmentation; different genes control paler skin in East Asians than in Europeans for example and some of the palest East Asians lack that common gene generally associated with paleness. You know this yourself; Uzbeks aren't black.

Look at Eastern Iranians isolated in eastern Central Asia like the Pamirs; they are descended from the Fatyanovo culture (Yamnaya-derived) and are pale, many are blue-eyed blonds. They're not super-pale and certainly many are duskier but it's telling you chose the Turkic-speaking Uzbeks with higher admixture over the Iranian-speaking groups like the Pashtuns, or better yet the more isolated & previously-mentioned Pamirs. The Kalash are the default people mentioned in contexts like these but they have also undergone a lot of admixture, which pulls them away from their original phenotype.

They were not twink pixies the color of moonlight but they were not the color of Turkics. I will admit that Uzbeks are not even THAT much darker than Clive, which makes it exceedingly bizarre you'd reject someone like him who otherwise represents the most common Yamnaya phenotype well. He has dark brown hair, brown beard and the general physical type.

>>10428458
That's not true, Negroids and Caucasoids diverged in Africa, and it was overwhelmingly the Caucasoids who left (although some Caucasoids lingered and some populations resembling Negroids left). That doesn't mean the Caucasoids and para-Caucasoids who left were identical to modern extant populations, but it does mean they weren't Negroids. They were a population distinct from other African groups; not just Negroids but also Negrillos/Pygmies/Central African Foragers, the East Bushmen, the South Bushmen and the Nilotes.

>>10428301
The chances are high that whatever steppe-population that actually gave rise to CWC had the alleles associated with light pigmentation present at a non-trivial frequency. All the populations of Europe today with high steppe-ancestry have high rates of blondism and blue eyes. In fact, the populations with the most steppe-ancestry stand out for their high rates of blondism and light pigmentation. Whoever sincerely believes that’s all coincidental is fooling himself. The fact that a subset of available samples from Yamnaya are somewhat dark means very little in the grand scheme of things. The ones that have been sampled are not even directly ancestral to CWC. And of course phenotypes were diverse also in the steppe, but steppe-populations to the north likely had lighter pigmentation.

com:
There are 6 places where human civilized history supposedly began independently:
>The Nile Valley (current Egypt)
>The Mesopotamian Valley (current Iraq)
>The Indus Valley (current Pakistan)
>The Huang He Valley (current China)
>The Andes Moutains (current Peru)
>The Mesoamerican Marshlands (current Mexico/Guatemala)
Aside from the Andes, all of them were born in places with easy access to fresh water.
The Mesopotamians and the Mesoamericans were the only ones who invented writing (independently), the others copied from them.

If you are asking about human pre-history, it depends on what you consider as "human". First hominids were found at East Africa, but that's debatable today. First modern Sapiens probably came from South Africa, but that's also debatable, but the consensus is they came from somewhere in Africa.

name: Anonymous

>>10429195
I think the Famine really was a watershed moment in Irish history. It was incontrovertible evidence that the British government quite simply just didn't care about them, at all.

There were always historical grievances, religious arguments and so on that nationalists could use to try and rally Irish people to the cause of independence. But the arguments for moderation and accepting the status quo were always quite strong also.

A struggle for independence would make an enemy of the most powerful country in the world. A struggle for independence would split the country along sectarian and semi-ethnic lines, as the Protestants of Ulster and the Anglo-Irish would be bound to fight it. Much of Ireland especially the East prospered from trade with the rest of the Empire. And so on.

And I think it's easy today for nationalists to pretend that those supporting the connection with Britain were only the Protestants and a handful of cringing "jackeens", but this was hardly the case. We only need look at Scotland today to realize what the attitude of a large minority was, again particularly in the East of the country. Especially after Emancipation, a very, very large proportion of the country was willing to think: Sure there's been a lot of trouble and suffering over the years, but we're in it together now, let's make the best of it.

But what actually happened in the Famine exposed a terrible truth: that at the time of greatest need, the British showed no pity, at all. They could have used their influence over the landlords of the West to force them to show mercy, they could have temporarily imposed emergency measures to stop evictions and this could have been done as a show of national solidarity at a time of need. But they didn't. They allowed men and women to be forced, forced onto the cold hard road to walk away, towards nothing and no-one willing to help them, to starve and die with the burning ruins of their house behind them. It was just dreadful.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>10429288
I actually agree with you about this, and that many Irish people have a simplistic notion that somehow Britain could wave a magic wand and bend economic reality. That said, they didn't do enough. If hundreds of thousands of people were starving in London or Manchester, they'd have moved quickly to really help them, but they didn't do the same for the Irish in the West. Even giving every concession for the fact that it was a remote part of the UK and they may not have realized initially how bad it was, it's hard to avoid the conclusion that on the whole, the problem just wasn't taken as seriously as it could have or should have.

And the people who should have been sounding the alarm at Westminster, the landlords of the West, were mostly thinking about the money they were going to lose because of their tenants not paying rent, not the fact that they were starving and dying. That's why, sad as it is that so many of the Big Houses were burn down in the 1920s, you can't help but somewhat understand why it happened.

I'll be perfectly honest, in general I have a sneaking admiration for the Anglo-Irish. Ireland's most distinguished sons and daughters were disproportionately born to this class of people who are of wholly English descent, and even if they were in a privileged position that helped them accomplish what they did, I can understand their pride, and their conflicted feelings towards the independence movement. I have them myself.

But the Famine was a really grave moral failing on their part. I don't think they deserve to have it held over their heads forever, but the fact that it is remembered with some bitterness is entirely understandable. Time will ultimately heal this wound, but it will take just that, time.

>>10429971
As I said prior, it all goes back to the rebellion in 1641. The rebellion itself was supposed to be quick and was planned to avoid civilian bloodshed; the Catholic nobles were going to seize several strategic points that would lock Ireland down-they'd then demand that the Graces (basically reforms to stop the persecution of Catholics) be granted as promised, before returning control. But the problem was that the plot was discovered-the nobles targeting Dublin were arrested, and the Dublin administration responded heavy-handedly. In return, the Catholic population thought "oh shit, they're coming for us-we'll get them first!" Meanwhile the actual plotters shit themselves as everything spirals out of control, until they formed the Confederate and restored a level of order.

Most of the massacres and atrocities committed were a result of both communities believing they were about to be wiped out-despite it being false on both accounts.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>10430626
Seán Lemass, economic wonderboy. He basically became Taoiseach and brought some "radical" reforms to expand Ireland's economy and do away with protectionism. He wanted big industry, lots of trade, and an increase in wealth from top to bottom. Foreign investment was made more attractive, free trade was encouraged, and domestic industries began to crop up. It was his view that Ireland was still relatively bogged down in old politics from the post-revolutionary days, with people stuck choosing what flavour of conservatism they wanted. With his reforms came social change-that encouraged people to spend more-which in turn helped out. Lemass was also a big advocate for Ireland's place within the EU.

In essence, he said it was time to set down the flags and the sabres and stop talking in rhetoric in favour of actually making the country he and others had fought for actually work. Lemass himself was an IRA assassin during the War of Independence. While of course the work wasn't all done by him, he is called the Father of Modern Ireland for a reason.

>>10429195
>The British government spent the 1840s exporting food from a nation where they were perfectly aware was starving to death.
>The British government owned all the land in Ireland
Come on, even for /his/ that's retarded. Ireland's land belonged to a patchwork of private landlords, many of them Catholic (the rules against Catholic land ownership having been repealed half a century before the start of the famine). The British government couldn't stop them from selling their produce where they liked because of property rights and all that jazz.

Also, what other people have said about food imports - the exports were mostly high-end produce like butter and beef that was exactly what was paying for the bulk goods like corn that kept the death toll as low as it was.

>due to British rule Irish tenants were left such little land that the only crop capable of feeding their families was the potato.
Could also have something to do with the fact that the population of Ireland almost doubled in the fifty years leading up to the famine.

>>10429266
>They could have used their influence over the landlords of the West to force them to show mercy,
Even Trevelyan thought the landlords were a pack of heartless jackals, and it didn't make a damn bit of difference. They tried to make the landlords pay to support their tenants but the landlords just reacted by evicting their tenants.

> towards nothing and no-one willing to help them,
The British government instituted a public works program that employed half a million Irishmen by the end of 1846. It was simply overwhelmed by the scale of the disaster - never in its history had the government had to organize anything like it. The civil service simply wasn't up to administering a project of that size.

>that at the time of greatest need, the British showed no pity, at all
The first Prime Minister during the famine, Robert Peel, put his entire political career on the line to pass legislation to make importing food to Ireland easier; repealing the Corn Laws basically destroyed himself and his party. He also arranged the purchase of £100,000 worth of American corn for use in relief efforts.

It was only after his government collapsed that Westminster stopped reacting quickly to reports of worse and worse food shortages in Ireland, but that was partly because Russel, who replaced him, was an old man leading a minority government, and had neither the energy or the power to lead the unprecedented top-to-bottom reforms that would have been needed to effectively combat the famine.

Nazi propagandist. To quote Justice Gray.

>Historians are human: they make mistakes, misread and misconstrue documents and overlook material evidence. I have found that, in numerous respects, Irving has misstated historical evidence; adopted positions which run counter to the weight of the evidence; given credence to unreliable evidence and disregarded or dismissed credible evidence. It appears to me that an analysis of those instances may shed light on the question whether Irving's misrepresentation of the historical evidence was deliberate.

> I have found that most of the Defendants' historiographical criticisms of Irving set out in section V of this judgement are justified. In the vast majority of those instances the effect of what Irving has written has been to portray Hitler in a favourable light and to divert blame from him onto others. I have held that this is unjustified by the evidence. Examples include Irving's portrayal of Hitler's conduct and attitude towards the events of Kristallnacht and the importance attached by Irving to Hitler's attitude towards the Jewish question as he claims is evidenced by the Schlegelberger note. I have seen no instance where Irving has misinterpreted the evidence or misstated the facts in a manner which is detrimental to Hitler. Irving appears to take every opportunity to exculpate Hitler.

1/2

>The same is true of the broader criticism made by the Defendants' of Irving's unwarrantedly favourable depiction of Hitler in regard to his attitude towards the Jews, which criticism I have found in section VI above to be justified. Irving sought in his writings to distance Hitler from the programme of shooting Jews in the East and from the later genocide in the death camps in a manner which the evidence did not warrant. Irving has argued, unjustifiably as I have found, that the evidence indicates that Hitler was unaware of any programme for the extermination of Jews at Auschwitz. In his account of the bombing of Dresden Irving (as I have found in section X1 above) persistently exaggerates the number of casualties, so enabling him to make comparisons between the number of civilians killed in Allied bombing raids with the number of Jews killed in the camps.

> Irving's claims to be a historian are bogus for a number of reasons. He has repeatedly condemned other historians for supposedly neglecting or suppressing key documents and for merely plagiarising each other; but how can he possibly do this, when on his own admission he never reads their work, and so can have no idea what is in it? At the Zündel trial in Canada, for example, he was even forced to admit that he had not read the standard work on the extermination of the Jews by Raul Hillberg. How can one take seriously the opinions of such a man on what professional historians do or fail to do? In fact, as we have seen, specialist historians do not merely rely on each other's work, but base their investigations on research in the archives that is at least as extensive as Irving's, and in most cases a good deal more rigorous. They cite other historians because other historians have carried out work on archival sources themselves, which it would be otiose to repeat. However, historians always provide precise references to the archival sources on which they base their conclusions, enabling their colleagues to check their accuracy and subject their arguments to critical scrutiny, and this is what commonly occurs when they use each other's work. By contrast, as we have seen, Irving frequently fails to provide proper source references, is often vague about the documents he claims to have used, and sometimes appears to cover his tracks by making it particularly difficult for his readers to track his sources down.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>10432512


> Moreover, far from reaching his conclusions about the Holocaust as a result of independent research, Irving, who admitted to a conference of the Institute of Historical Review in the mid-1980's that he had never investigated it in any detail since it was not his primary concern, has simply copied them from the existing literature of Holocaust denial, in the kind of incestuous and plagiaristic procedure which he has repeatedly and falsely alleged is common practice among academic historians. Examining the views of App, Butz, Faurisson, Rassinier, Staeglich, Christophersen and others quoted and summarized in this paper, it is clear that many of them have been taken over completely by Irving without acknowledgment and presented as his own. Thus his argument that Zyklon-B was only used for delousing and hygiene - for saving lives rather than taking them, in other words - was put much earlier by Butz. So too was his claim that the failure of Yad Vashem to collect six million names showed that six million did not in fact die. Irving's assertion that Auschwitz was no more than an industrial plant also appears to derive from Butz. His belief that most Jews who died there died of typhus can also be found in Butz's The Hoax of the Twentieth Century, published long before Irving announced in public his conversion to Holocaust denial. He follows Butz in his semantic disputation of the meaning of terms such as Judentum and Ausrottung. He echoes Austin App in the suggestion that a large number of the Jews who allegedly died in the Holocaust went to Israel and were not killed at all.

2/5

According to the 2018 US Census Bureau estimates, the population of Texas was 73.5% White (41.4% Non-Hispanic White and 32.1% Hispanic White), 12.3% Black or African American, 5.0% Asian, 0.5% Native American and Alaskan Native, 0.1% Pacific Islander, 6.0% Some Other Race, and 2.7% from two or more races.

English Americans predominate in eastern, central, and northern Texas; German Americans, in central and western Texas. African Americans, who historically made up one-third of the state population, are concentrated in parts of northern, eastern and east-central Texas as well as in the Dallas-Fort Worth, Houston and San Antonio metropolitan areas.

As in other Southern states settled largely in the 19th century, the vast majority have European ancestry: Irish, English and German.[10] Texas includes a diverse set of European ancestries, due both to historical patterns of settlement from the Southeastern United States, as well as contemporary dynamics. Frontier Texas saw settlements of Germans, particularly in Fredericksburg and New Braunfels. Many Romanians, Dutch, Germans from Switzerland and Austria, Poles, Russians, Swedes, Norwegians, Czechs, Slovaks, Italians, and French immigrated at least in part because of the European revolutions of 1848. This immigration continued until World War I and the 1920s. The influence of these diverse European immigrants survives in the town names, architectural styles, music, and cuisine in Texas.

Lavaca County, for example, is over one-quarter Czech American, Seguin has a large Slovak American community, and Nederland has many Dutch Americans whose ancestors immigrated from the Netherlands.

It is 100% ridiculous to believe that something existed with quite literally zero evidence for it.

>instead descended from them much the like the alligator or crocodile
Crocodiles and alligators are not descended from dinosaurs. If this hypothetical animal was descended from dinosaurs then it would be a dinosaur. Learn how cladistics work.

>either most were destroyed
Why would they be destroyed when dinosaur bones were not? Why are they exempt from the fossil record? Bones just don't sit around and wait for someone to dig them up. Bones are only found when they're exposed to the elements via erosion and will quickly be destroyed by those same forces if they aren't preserved. We aren't digging up the same sites that our ancestors did.

>Just haven't found them yet.
Every single extant large bodied organism has an evolutionary history that is preserved in the fossil record. Why would your fairy tale wishful thinking be exempt?

Just so you know, even though I don't do it professionally, I am a trained paleontologist and have a dumb little uni certificate in evolutionary biology. This is not an argument you're going to win.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>10427367
>Every single extant large bodied organism has an evolutionary history that is preserved in the fossil record.
I'm sorry what? Correct me if I'm wrong but isn't fossilization by definition rare? Isn't that actually one of the main problems facing paleontology? That useful fossilization only ever occurs under very specific circumstances and as such the actual known demonstrable evolutionary history of everything, while certainly not guessed at, requires a fair bit of estimation, revision and constant updating?

To the point that affirmations made today can and sometimes are entirely worthless 5 years from now.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>10427583
Fossilization is extremely rare but there have been quadrillions of animals in Earth's history. The fossil record while far far from complete, is actually very informative and there are very few huge evolutionary mysteries left. Especially the more recently you go in time (humans are a pretty notably confusing and convoluted exception but we still have thousands of paleolithic humans in the fossil record.)

>To the point that affirmations made today can and sometimes are entirely worthless 5 years from now.
This is much bigger problem for animals from the distant past with no modern analogues or relatives like non avian dinosaurs.

All this said, my point still stands. If he had a hypothetical animal that was larger than a human, it would be the only one on earth that does not have at least one ancestor/close offshoot absent from the fossil record between the Holocene and the K-Pg.

I'm a Magyar man. My father was called Attila. He was also Magyar. His father, another Magyar, was called Attila, too. And his father, my great-grandfather, is from the same stock. He was called Árpád. I'm posting here as a representative of all of them.

Our Prime Minister once spoke of the destruction of ancient Athens and the miraculous survival in the blackened ruins of that city of the sacred olive tree; the symbol of Greece, their country. And he also spoke of us, the Magyars, at the heart of a vanished empire, seeming to find within ourselves that one of our own oak trees, the sap rising from our ancient roots, and he said perhaps, after all, we who have inhabited the Pannonian Basin for an unbroken thousand years, brought up, as he said, within the sound of Magyar bird song under the Magyar oak, in the Magyar meadow, beneath the Holy Crown of St. Stephen, it is us who know most of Central Europe.

And I appreciated him for saying that, because it was as if he spoke for my family.

Am I irredentist? No. Do I have anything against people from neighboring countries? No. So what then is my gripe?

name: Anonymous
com:
>>10432543
My gripe is quite simple. My gripe is that we were never asked. My gripe is that we were told, not asked, and everyday we are told again and again how we should feel about our history and what our borders are to be. We are told by them, and we know who they are, they used to be Hungarians, too.

They are the former minorities who have always set themselves apart, they are the ones who have taken from us what they wanted for themselves, and now they are the ones giving Central Europe away.

They have never asked us, and they never will.

Do we allow them to sell our sovereignty? Or is it time for us to speak? To speak, to refuse them the right to give away our holy, or bountiful, our only Hungary that has nurtured us, naked, grown us as the oak. Is it time for us that Hungary know to come yet again and defend our freedom? With our fire, our fists?

Is it time for us Magyars to rise again?

I say yes.
I say yes.
I say…
Yes.

>>10427725
The British. It was not driven by benevolence but the end result was the same - the idea of the 'White Man's burden' was essentially the easiest way to justify imperialism to a domestic audience that abhorred slavery and generally speaking wanted to "do good" (in the biblical sense). You can see it in Kipling:

Take up the White Man's burden—
Send forth the best ye breed—
Go bind your sons to exile
To serve your captives' need;

Take up the White Man's burden—
The savage wars of peace—
Fill full the mouth of Famine
And bid the sickness cease;

Take up the White Man's burden—
No tawdry rule of kings,
But toil of serf and sweeper—
The tale of common things.
The ports ye shall not enter,
The roads ye shall not tread,
Go make them with your living,
And mark them with your dead!

It's basically all an attempt to argue that what colonial powers were doing was a service to the colonised - an act of charity that cost the coloniser alot but was done for the betterment of the colony. It was a way to justify the sentiment in pic related

name: Anonymous
com:
Most of Africa wasn't like Ethiopia. And when the Europeans came across those Africans who were more "civilised" and useful, they were treated somewhat differently.

You had Europeans, you had their native trading partners and sometimes allies (mostly the rulers of coastal states and their own vassals/allied families) who helped them establish trading factories and supplied them with the African goods they needed including but not limited to slaves, and then you had the bulk of the African native population usually in the interior, who were basically preyed on by those more powerful groups along the coast, who used the weapons and tactics they had obtained from the Europeans to subjugate, enslave, and delivery them into the hands of the Europeans for profit.

--

To be clear, this was obviously terrible and the European lust for wealth and indifference to the cruelty they were visiting on these human beings was what was ultimately responsible for what happened. It's nevertheless true though that not all Africans were treated alike. Those obviously more advanced, capable, powerful and often useful were treated differently from the rest, and this tendency increased as time went on because of Social Darwinist ideas, although race autism also meant that in the early 20th century there was also a tendency to treat anyone not European as unconditionally inferior.

com: Everyone ITT are retards, derailers, or simply prejudiced (why even reply to a thread you don't care about or like?). I am going to answer OP's question. Eritrea has been a separate kingdom from Ethiopia for hundreds of years, called Medri Bahri. The Italians absorbed most of this kingdom since the Eritreans saw Italians as allies to fight against the Ethiopians. After colonization was over, Eritrea was its own autonomous country in coalition with Ethiopia. The Ethiopian king Haile Selassie broke this federation and forcefully annexed Eritrea in 1962. The movement for Eritrean independence started after this. It ended up being a full-scale war after the communist Derg massacred Eritrean villages and caused a famine that affected millions of people. Eritrea successfully won this war of independence after winning the Battle of Afabet and the Derg was on its last legs after the collapses of the Eastern Bloc. Since the border between Eritrea and Ethiopia hasn't been properly demarcated a border war ensued and Ethiopia has been occupying Eritrean land till this day. Recently, the president Isais Afwerki has started supporting Abi Ahmeds new administration in order to disempower their perceived enemies: The tigrayans.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>10422056
It's a complicated history filled with ethnic politics and competing political factions.

Eritrean independence goes back to the Italian period and won a fair bit of support, but the Ethiopian annexation definitely saw the two countries further integrated.

It was the overthrow of the monarchy and the subsequent rise of ethnically based and often ideologically divided rebel groups during that time that created the current conflict. More or less, old ideas were reignited amidst the backdrop of growing Tigray leadership of the anti-Derg struggle.

These Tigrays would be successful, becoming the dominant ethnic group in the new Ethiopia, but their ethnic brethren in Eritrea would continue to fight for independence.

The idea that Eritreans are fifth columnists more or less permeated throughout Ethiopia during the years of Tigray dominance.

Only now that said dominance has ended is their relationship starting to heal, though the totalitarian regime in Eritrea will probably continue to make reconciliation a problem.

Any time French governments negotiated with the Haitians, it was obvious that all those who had lost their fortunes to the revolution would demand that France properly represent their interest, and act accordingly to ensure they were compensated.

It's easy to sit in your chair hundreds of years later and call it monstrous (even if it was) but if you were a merchant in France, maybe you'd never visited Saint-Domingue even once, all you know or at least really care about is that you're out of pocket substantially because of what the rebels-turned-government-of-Haiti did to your property or the property of one of your associates. >But once the Napoleonic Wars were over and France at peace with its fellow Europeans, Haiti no longer stood a single chance against France.

This would seem to be a reasonable idea, if it wasn't for the sheer ferocity with which yellow fever decimated any foreign troops sent to the island. I'm sure that had Napoleon amassed a veritably biblical army and sent it to the island (like 100,000+ troops) victory against the rebels would have been possible.

BUT after the losses already suffered, it would have been deeply unpopular. Being sent to the island inspired such fear and horror among the British troops being amassed to replace those occupying Môle Saint-Nicolas, who had been decimated by yellow fever, that riots broke out at naval installations in Britain itself in protest at their being sent there.

Being sent to Haiti wasn't a death sentence, but it wasn't not a death sentence, either. If you were a French soldier in some port city, realizing that if you accepted your deployment there was a 1/3 chance you were going to be killed by yellow fever even before you had a chance to fight any rebels, how would you feel? What might you do to avoid it?

And desu, it appears from the record that Haitians did not really relish the task of carrying out Dessalinnes' orders. Since everyone on the island was complicit in upholding slavery apart from the maroons (albeit the slaves unwillingly, an important detail), it's easy to see how if you were an average Haitian, you might not have any particular hatred for the white man or woman that happened to be living in your neighbourhood.

A blacksmith that yes, makes and repairs tools at an ironmongery that does include those used on plantations, does he necessarily deserve to die? A storekeeper who sells to anyone with the money to pay? A schoolmaster?

Apparently, the answer from most Haitians was initially, "No," which is why Dessalines visited each major town of the island, to ensure that his orders were carried out. Those who refused, were themselves ordered killed.

Apparently, he also specifically singled out mulattoes to kill the whites, because he didn't want it to go down in history that only blacks were responsible for the massacre.
